description.narrative: This project will conserve biodiversity and ecosystem services in three critical landscapes of the Central Forest Spine, by supporting the country’s CFS Master Plan to restore connectivity between forest complexes.
capital of a political entity

Biodiversity and ecosystem service provision is mainstreamed in forest landscape management in the three priority landscapes via sustainable forest landscape management plans resulting in maintained status of biodiversity and ecosystem services

A score of at least 9 by end of project

description.narrative: Multistakeholder landscape management plan implemented in each landscape informed by biodiversity ecosystem services and carbon stocks values

comment.narrative: Currently only BelumTemengor has an integrated landscape management plan formed without the use of environmental monitoring and management planning tools
693500 ha across the three focal landscapes is under improved management incorporating environmental monitoring and management tools

description.narrative: Enhanced wildlife crime law enforcement and wildlife monitoring capacity emplaced at national and state levels and in target forest landscapes to ensure reduction of wildlife and forestry crime

comment.narrative: Between 2011 and 2012 just 13 of cases recorded by DWNP were prosecuted in court
At least 70 of recorded wildlife crime cases are prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalty

description.narrative: Tiger populations in source PAs

comment.narrative: Estimated to be 03 individuals per 10000 ha
Population increased by at least 20

The Wildlife Conservation TWG have completed discussions with stakeholders especially on tiger population targets indicators The TWG has decided to change the tiger population density from 03 individuals per 10000 ha to 08 individuals per 100km2 based on recent studies by MYCAT and PERHILITAN The tiger survey by respective organisations including WWFM PERHILITAN and WCS is ongoing
Population increased by at least 20

The Wildlife Conservation TWG have completed discussions with stakeholders especially on tiger population targets indicators The TWG has decided to change the tiger population density from 03 individuals per 10000 ha to 08 individuals per 100km2 based on recent studies by MYCAT and PERHILITAN The tiger survey by respective organisations including WWFM PERHILITAN and WCS is ongoing

description.narrative: Funding allocations for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS are secured and formalised
Coordinated mechanism in place for attracting earmarking and administering funding for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS

comment.narrative: Fundraising and financial flows for conservation in the CFS largely uncoordinated between different agencies and organisations

With significantly reduced dependence on funds from federal budgets and NGOs the conservation of the CFS is directed and managed via the dedicated fund without influence of national economic circumstances
The TWG at the Forestry Department will keep track of this Recent government approval of RM50 million for wildlife Survey is very encouraging

description.narrative: Strategic planning processes in place and being used to link financing to conservation management needs
CFS conservation management is supported by sustainable financing plans

comment.narrative: Budget preparation and planning in government conservation agencies largely delinked from CFS conservation management plans
One CFSwide and 3 statelevel sustainable financing plans ensure that landscapes are managed sustainably dependent in the long term on the values of their biodiversity and ecosystem services
Expected to be carried out in 2018

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional capacity of the Federal Government to oversee implementation of the CFSMP ensuring compliance by subnational actors and monitoring impacts upon biodiversity ecosystems and carbon stocks
National CFS steering committee equipped to apply environmental monitoring and management tools in supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP

comment.narrative: National CFS steering committee has little knowledge on applications of environmental considerations in landscape management planning and monitoring

National CFS steering committee is fully trained in the application of the tools developed under Outputs 111114 for supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP
The outputs for these are not carried out yet This is expected to be done in year 3 after the tools are done between year 1 and year 3

description.narrative: The socioeconomic status of local communities improved and support for conservation increased through the generation of sustainable livelihoods based on wildlife and the reduction of humanwildlife conflict
Conservationrelated livelihood activities involving both men and women established in pilot areas and making significant contributions to household income of Orang Asli participants

comment.narrative: Baseline household income gained from different livelihood activities undertaken by both men and women to be established at start of project disaggregated by gender Some craft groups exist in BelumTemengor but have been given little support and opportunity to develop
At least two ecotourism and handicrafts CBOs in operation with proven engagement of both men and women and increasing household income of participants by 25

Outputs regarding 231 on ecotourism led by both FDPM and PERHILITAN is ongoing In relation to this the Johor TWG is in the process of being established with the involvement of DWNP and other relevant agencies An elephant sanctuary is in the process of being gazetted

- Natural forest of 4 forest blocks of CFS protected and managed well (Main Range Forest Complex, Southeast Pahang Peat Swamp Forest, Greater Taman Negara complex, Endau-Rompin-Sedili complex)
- Funds for CFS conservation developed and invested (apart from GEF funds)
- Overall score of CFS Capacity Development Scorecard raised

- 4.5 million ha of PRF and National Park in CFS complexes
- Currently mostly government or ad hoc NGO funding
- Current capacity score card is 12

The project underwent an Independent Rapid Review from November 2017 to June 2018. The IRR was engaged by UNDP HQ due to the unsatisfactory performance of the project. During the IRR period, the project was put on hold. Some of the recommendations from the IRR included: IRR recommendations: >Project Design --must apply a holistic, integrated and participatory strategy to the planning and management of the 3 target landscapes >Project management and governance:- 1. Establish an independent Adaptive Management Advisory Panel (AMAP); 2. Establish an External Technical Advisory Panel; 3. Recruit a full-time Technical Project Manager and project team including an M&E expert; 4. Review the roles of 28 project-supported staff; and 5. Review and adopt the revised ToR for PSC. >Strategic Results Framework (SRF)-- Needs to be reviewed and submit proposed changes to PSC for approval >Project Implementation Reviews-- Reporting needs to be strengthened and made more robust >Communications--Develop and implement a Communication Strategy and Action Plan

Malaysia’s 14th General Election in May of 2018 resulted in a change in government. This led to a period of consolidation and adjustment within the federal government ministries and departments. This further led to delays in appointing the members of the Adaptive Management Advisory Panel (AMAP) by the (then) Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE). The AMAP members were officially appointed in December of 2018. The IRR recommendations were addressed only after the AMAP was appointed.

The Strategic Results Framework (SRF) and Adaptive Management Action Plan were revised and finalized in consultation with KATS and UNDP Country Office and Regional Technical Adviser. The SRF was endorsed by the Project Steering Committee (PSC) on 23rd September 2019. The project will submit extension request by March 2020.

Project exceptional extension request up 43 months has been submitted to UNDP-NCE Executive Coordinators approval at the end of March 2020. Awaiting for official communication on the project extension request.

The project received conditional extension approval on 13 May 2020 from UNDP Nature, Climate and Energy (UNDP-NCE) until 31 December 2023 with the extension for year 2022 and 2023 is conditioned upon the project’s achievement of key milestones agreed for year 2021 and 2022. The key milestones to obtain extension for year 2022 are: • Project Implementation Review rated as Moderately Satisfactory or higher • Mid Term Review rated as Moderately Satisfactory or higher overall with sustainability rated as Moderately Likely or higher • Monitoring tool for biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks developed • Integrated SMART patrolling initiative piloted in one State • Management plan for Johor (Panti - Ulu Sedili) ecological corridor developed • CFS sustainable finance plan for one state drafted

On top of the key milestones set up by UNDP-NCE (refer above), the targets as per revised Strategic Results Framework are: 1) No net loss of forested area, with 95% remaining natural forest; CFS conservation fund receiving regular income through diverse sources; Score of at least 22 by project end 2) 3 scopes of technical input namely biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks incorporated into the decision-making papers; 3 decision making papers submitted to the targeted state EXCOs/federal council/Cabinet; At least one decision making paper approved at state/federal level; A one stop center for biodiversity, ecosystem services, carbon stocks, etc. operationalized and used by relevant stakeholders. 3) One tool for monitoring of biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks developed, piloted and adopted by federal and state technical agencies and stakeholders. 4) Tiger population in CFS landscape increased by at least 20%; At least 30% of recorded wildlife crime cases are prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalties; The percentage of enforcement staff doing enforcement work in the landscape is known; The job scope (Senarai Tugas) of these enforcement staff is complied with. 5) At least five state forestry officers and state park officers are delegated powers under the WCA 2010 in each targeted state; At least ten forestry officers and state park officers involved in six integrated enforcement activities annually (Two per target site). 6) At least ten community rangers appointed by administration/legal means in targeted landscape; Three communities effectively undertake wildlife monitoring and enforcement in targeted landscape; One WildFriend programme operationalized at one target state 7) One decision making paper prepared and submitted for a common data sharing platform related to wildlife and forestry crime at federal level; SMART based patrolling system is developed, adopted, implemented and shared by DWNP, state forestry, state parks and other related stakeholders at target states; At least four SOP(s) related to arresting, handling of seized item, investigation and prosecution for state parks developed; The different types of intelligence technology identified, piloted and assessed at sites including real-time surveillance system. 8) A systematic capacity building programme related to monitoring of biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks developed and implemented at targeted CFS landscapes; DWNP and Forestry Department are capacity built for wildlife and forestry crime monitoring, intelligence, investigation and prosecution at federal and state levels. 9) Three CFS management plans for each of the targeted landscapes incorporating protocols on biodiversity, ecosystem services, carbon stocks and monitoring. 10) At least 629 ha of degraded forest landscapes in line with ARR methodology, using a mix of native species, in accordance with current plans within the CFSMP rehabilitated. 11) At least 20,000 ha of critical corridor areas identified and gazetted at the three targetted states. 12) At least 3 district local plans incorporate the relevant ecological corridors. 13) At least 100 of indigenous peoples involved in livelihood related projects in Taman Negara, Belum-Temengor and Endau-Rompin; An increase in household income of indigenous people involved by 10% in the piloted projects. 14) Baseline for economic losses due to HEC within the indigenous communities is known; A guideline developed for non-consumptive wildlife tourism in HEC area; Non-consumptive wildlife tourism in synergy with HEC is piloted in one target HEC site. 15) Staff of at least 2 state planning and CFS implementation agencies trained using these standard training programmes; Two training modules for non-consumptive wildlife tourism programme within CFS developed; One CFS Communications Plan (e.g. awareness and advocacy strategy) in Forestry Department Peninsular Malaysia developed; One dedicated CFS Counterpart Officer at each state; One effective communications programme for CBOs developed and implemented. 16) At least USD 1 million acquired from new and additional sources of funding for CFS; At least 1 additional MOU/MOA for funding sources signed between donor and receiver. 17) At least one entity established to collect and disburse funds for conservation and sustainable management of CFS; Trustee membership to include non-governmental organisation and transparent governance measures; Budgeting criteria developed to disburse funds for CFS related activities; A list of eligibility criteria drawn up for traditional and non-traditional stakeholders to access the funds. 18) GoM continue to allocate on an annual basis funding for CFSMP implementation; Outcome-based budgeting criteria for CFS funding developed and adopted by technical agencies; Monitoring and reporting mechanism for the CFS funding is established for the state; Information on economic valuation of the CFS landscape is available for the state. 19) One State has incorporated sustainable financing considerations into the CFS state plan and into their annual budget.
